title: Receptacle Outlets - Dwelling Unit Spacing
summary: Receptacles shall be installed such that no point along the floor line of any wall space is more than 6 feet from a receptacle outlet. Receptacles shall be no more than 12 feet apart.
common_questions: How far apart should outlets be?
What is the maximum spacing for electrical outlets?
How many outlets do I need in a room?
notes: Wall space includes any space 2 feet or more in width. Doorways, fireplaces, and similar openings do not break wall space.

title: Kitchen Countertop Receptacles
summary: Receptacle outlets shall be installed at kitchen countertops so that no point along the wall line is more than 24 inches from a receptacle outlet.
common_questions: How far apart should kitchen outlets be?
Do I need outlets above kitchen counters?
notes: Receptacles shall be located above, but not more than 20 inches above, the countertop.

title: GFCI Protection - Bathrooms
summary: All 125-volt, single-phase, 15- and 20-ampere receptacles installed in bathrooms shall have ground-fault circuit-interrupter (GFCI) protection.
common_questions: Do I need GFCI in bathroom?
Is GFCI required for bathroom outlets?
notes: This includes all receptacles, not just those near water sources.

title: Stair Riser Height
summary: The maximum riser height shall be 7-3/4 inches. The riser shall be measured vertically between leading edges of the adjacent treads.
common_questions: How tall can stair risers be?
What is code for stair height?
notes: The greatest riser height within any flight of stairs shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch.

title: Stair Tread Depth
summary: The minimum tread depth shall be 10 inches. The tread depth shall be measured horizontally between the vertical planes of the foremost projection of adjacent treads.
common_questions: How deep should stair treads be?
What is code for stair tread?
notes: The greatest tread depth within any flight of stairs shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch.

title: Kitchen Sink Drain Size
summary: Kitchen sinks shall have a minimum 1-1/2 inch diameter drain pipe.
common_questions: What size drain pipe for kitchen sink?
Minimum pipe size for kitchen drain?
notes: Garbage disposals typically require the same minimum size.

title: GFCI Protection - Garages
summary: All 125-volt, single-phase, 15- and 20-ampere receptacles installed in garages shall have ground-fault circuit-interrupter protection for personnel.
notes: Exception: Receptacles that are not readily accessible, such as ceiling-mounted receptacles for garage door openers.

title: GFCI Protection - Sinks
summary: Receptacles installed within 6 feet of the outside edge of a sink shall have GFCI protection.
common_questions: Do outlets near sinks need GFCI?
notes: Applies to sinks located in areas other than kitchens (laundry rooms, basements, etc.)

title: Lighting Outlets Required - Habitable Rooms
summary: At least one wall switch-controlled lighting outlet shall be installed in every habitable room and bathroom.
common_questions: Do all rooms need a light switch?
notes: In kitchens and bathrooms, the lighting outlet shall be ceiling or wall-mounted.

title: NM Cable - Securing and Supporting
summary: Nonmetallic-sheathed cable shall be secured within 12 inches of every cabinet, box, or fitting, and supported at intervals not exceeding 4.5 feet.
common_questions: How often do you staple Romex?
notes: Cable shall be secured by staples, cable ties, straps, or similar fittings.

title: Appliance Access for Maintenance
summary: Appliances shall be accessible for inspection, service, repair and replacement without removing permanent construction or building components.
notes: A level working space at least 30 inches deep and 30 inches wide shall be provided in front of the control side.

title: Protection of Pipes - Freezing
summary: Water, soil and waste pipes shall not be installed outside of a building, in attics or crawl spaces, or in any other place where they may be subjected to freezing temperatures unless adequate provision is made to protect such pipes from freezing.
common_questions: How to protect pipes from freezing?
notes: Protection may include insulation, heat tape, or routing pipes in conditioned spaces.

title: Shower Receptors - General
summary: Shower receptors shall have a finished curb threshold not less than 1 inch below the sides and back of the receptor.
common_questions: How tall should shower curb be?
notes: The curb shall be not less than 2 inches and not more than 9 inches deep when measured from the top of the curb to the top of the drain.

title: Floor Elevations at Doors
summary: Landings or floors at the required egress door shall not be more than 1.5 inches lower than the top of the threshold.
common_questions: How much can door threshold drop?
notes: Exception: The landing at an exterior doorway shall not be more than 7.75 inches below the top of the threshold provided the door does not swing over the landing.

title: Minimum Vent Area - Attics
summary: The minimum net free ventilating area shall be 1/150 of the area of the vented space.
common_questions: How much attic ventilation do I need?
notes: The minimum may be reduced to 1/300 when a vapor retarder is installed on the warm side of the ceiling and at least 50% of the venting is in the upper portion of the attic.

title: Foundation Anchorage
summary: Sill plates shall be anchored to foundations with anchor bolts spaced not more than 6 feet apart, with at least two bolts per piece and located within 12 inches of each end.
common_questions: How far apart are foundation anchor bolts?
notes: Bolts shall be at least 1/2 inch in diameter and shall extend at least 7 inches into concrete or masonry.

title: Small-Appliance Branch Circuits - Dwelling Units
summary: In addition to the number of branch circuits required by other parts of this section, two or more 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits shall be provided for all receptacle outlets specified by 210.52(B).
common_questions: How many kitchen circuits do I need?
notes: These circuits shall have no other outlets and shall serve the kitchen, dining room, breakfast room, pantry, or similar areas.

title: Laundry Branch Circuits
summary: At least one 20-ampere branch circuit shall be provided to supply the laundry receptacle outlet(s) required by 210.52(F). This circuit shall have no other outlets.
common_questions: Does laundry room need dedicated circuit?
notes: The laundry circuit must be 20-ampere and dedicated solely to laundry receptacles.

title: Outdoor Receptacle Outlets - Dwelling Units
summary: For one- and two-family dwellings, at least one receptacle outlet shall be installed outdoors at the front and back of the dwelling at a readily accessible location at grade level.
common_questions: How many outdoor outlets are required?
notes: All outdoor receptacles must be GFCI protected per NEC 210.8(A)(3).

title: GFCI Protection - Outdoor Outlets
summary: All 125-volt through 250-volt receptacles supplied by single-phase branch circuits rated 150 volts or less to ground, 50 amperes or less, and installed outdoors shall have GFCI protection.
notes: This applies to all outdoor receptacles in all occupancies.

title: Heating, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration Equipment Outlet
summary: A 125-volt, single-phase, 15- or 20-ampere receptacle outlet shall be installed at an accessible location for the servicing of heating, air-conditioning, and refrigeration equipment.
common_questions: Does HVAC need a dedicated outlet?
notes: The receptacle shall be located on the same level and within 25 feet of the heating, air-conditioning, and refrigeration equipment.

title: Box Fill Calculations
summary: Boxes shall be of sufficient size to provide free space for all enclosed conductors. The minimum volume shall be calculated using conductor fill requirements.
common_questions: How many wires can fit in a junction box?
notes: Each conductor counts as follows: 14 AWG = 2 cubic inches, 12 AWG = 2.25 cubic inches, 10 AWG = 2.5 cubic inches.

title: Tamper-Resistant Receptacles
summary: All nonlocking type 125-volt, 15- and 20-ampere receptacles in dwelling unit areas specified in 210.52 shall be listed tamper-resistant receptacles.
notes: This requirement applies to all areas where 125V, 15A and 20A receptacles are required by 210.52.

title: Working Space Around Electrical Equipment
summary: Working space for equipment operating at 600 volts or less shall be not less than 3 feet wide and 30 inches deep, extending from the floor to 6.5 feet above the floor.
common_questions: How much clearance around electrical panel?
notes: The working space shall be clear and extend from the grade, floor, or platform to the height required. Storage is not permitted in this space.

title: Trenching, Excavation and Backfill
summary: Trenches shall be excavated to the depth and width required. The bottom of the trench shall provide a uniform bearing for the pipe.
common_questions: How deep should sewer pipe be buried?
notes: Backfill shall be free from objects that could damage the pipe. Piping shall be laid on a bed of sand or gravel at least 4 inches deep.

title: Minimum Number of Fixtures
summary: Plumbing fixtures shall be provided in the minimum number as shown in Table 403.1 for the type of occupancy and number of occupants.
common_questions: How many bathrooms do I need?
notes: For residential: At least 1 water closet, 1 lavatory, 1 bathtub or shower, and 1 kitchen sink are required.

title: Hot Water Supply System Requirements
summary: All plumbing fixtures and equipment used for bathing, washing, culinary purposes, cleansing, laundry or building maintenance shall be supplied with hot water.
common_questions: How hot should hot water be?
notes: Hot water shall be supplied to required fixtures at a temperature of not less than 110°F (43°C) and not greater than 120°F (49°C).

title: Fixture Trap Requirements
summary: Each plumbing fixture shall be separately trapped by a water seal trap. The trap shall be placed as close as possible to the fixture outlet.
common_questions: Does every drain need a trap?
How close should trap be to fixture?
notes: The vertical distance from fixture outlet to trap weir shall not exceed 24 inches.

title: Vent Required
summary: Every building in which plumbing fixtures are installed shall have a vent system. The vent system shall be designed to admit air to the drainage system.
notes: Vents prevent siphoning of traps and allow for proper drainage. Every trap must be vented.

title: Water Supply Fixture Units
summary: Water supply systems shall be sized for the total demand on the system using the fixture unit method in accordance with Table 604.3.
common_questions: What size water pipe do I need?
notes: Common residential: 3/4 inch for main, 1/2 inch for branch lines to fixtures.

title: Cleanouts Required
summary: Cleanouts shall be installed at intervals of not more than 100 feet for 4-inch and smaller pipes. Changes of direction exceeding 45 degrees shall have a cleanout.
common_questions: Where do cleanouts need to be?
How often do I need cleanouts?
notes: Cleanouts shall be installed at the base of each waste stack and at changes in direction greater than 45 degrees.

title: Hot Water System Controls
summary: Water heaters shall be equipped with temperature controls to limit the maximum temperature of water delivered from the water heater to 120°F (49°C).
notes: Prevents scalding. Some applications may require tempering valves to further limit temperature.

title: Floor Joist Spans
summary: Floor joist spans for common lumber species shall be in accordance with Tables R502.3.1(1) and R502.3.1(2). Spans are based on joist size, spacing, and lumber grade.
common_questions: How far can floor joists span?
notes: Example: 2x10 #2 grade at 16 inches on center can span approximately 16 feet for living areas.

title: Stud Size and Spacing
summary: Exterior and bearing wall studs shall be 2x4 or larger at 16 inches on center or 2x6 at 24 inches on center. Non-bearing walls may use 2x4 at 24 inches on center.
common_questions: How far apart should wall studs be?
Can I use 2x4 for exterior walls?
notes: Maximum stud spacing is 24 inches on center. Utility grade studs shall not be spaced more than 16 inches on center.

title: Protection Against Decay
summary: Wood in contact with the ground or in areas of high moisture shall be naturally durable wood or preservative-treated wood.
common_questions: What wood can touch the ground?
notes: Required for sills and sleepers on concrete or masonry, wood joists within 18 inches of exposed ground, and posts or columns in contact with ground.

title: Deck Joist Spans
summary: Deck joists shall be sized according to Table R507.5 based on joist span, spacing, and lumber species.
common_questions: How far can deck joists span?
notes: Example: 2x8 Southern Pine at 16 inches on center can span approximately 11 feet.

title: Deck Ledger Connection to Band Joist
summary: Deck ledgers shall be minimum 2x8 nominal lumber and shall be connected to the band joist with 1/2-inch lag screws or bolts with washers spaced per Table R507.2.3(1).
common_questions: How to attach deck ledger to house?
Lag screw spacing for deck ledger
notes: This is a critical structural connection. Typical spacing is 16 inches on center for 1/2-inch lag screws.

title: Rafter Spans
summary: Rafter spans shall be in accordance with Tables R802.4.1(1) through R802.4.1(8) based on rafter size, spacing, species, and roof load.
common_questions: How far can roof rafters span?
notes: Example: 2x6 rafters at 16 inches on center can span approximately 13 feet for typical residential roofs.

title: Stairway Handrail Height
summary: Handrails shall be not less than 34 inches nor more than 38 inches above the nosing of treads and landings.
common_questions: How high should stair handrail be?
notes: Handrail height is measured vertically from the sloped plane adjoining the tread nosing.

title: Guard Height
summary: Guards on open sides of stairways, landings, balconies or porches that are more than 30 inches above grade shall be not less than 36 inches in height.
common_questions: How tall does deck railing need to be?
notes: Openings in guards shall not allow passage of a 4-inch diameter sphere.

title: Minimum Depth of Footings
summary: Footings shall be placed at least 12 inches below undisturbed ground surface. Where applicable, footings shall extend below the frost line.
notes: Frost depth varies by location. Check local amendments for your area's frost depth requirement.

title: Header Requirements
summary: Headers shall be provided over each opening in load-bearing walls. Headers shall be sized according to Tables R602.7(1) and R602.7(2).
common_questions: What size header do I need?
notes: Example: 4-foot window opening in a one-story building typically requires a double 2x6 header.

title: Appliance Access
summary: Appliances shall be accessible for inspection, service, repair, and replacement without removing permanent construction or any other appliances.
common_questions: Can I enclose my water heater?
notes: A level working space at least 30 inches deep and 30 inches wide shall be provided in front of the control side of the appliance.

title: Return Air Limitations
summary: Return air shall not be taken from a closet, bathroom, toilet room, kitchen, garage, mechanical room, furnace room, or unconditioned attic.
common_questions: Where can return air vents be located?
Can return air be in bathroom?
notes: Return air openings cannot be within 10 feet of any appliance using fossil fuel.

title: Duct Insulation - Exterior
summary: Supply ducts in attics and other unconditioned spaces shall be insulated to a minimum of R-8. Return ducts shall be insulated to a minimum of R-6.
common_questions: Do ducts in attic need insulation?
notes: Ducts in conditioned space may not require insulation. Check local energy code requirements.

title: Appliance Shutoff Valve
summary: Each appliance shall be provided with a shutoff valve separate from the gas meter. The shutoff valve shall be located in the same room as the appliance.
common_questions: Do gas appliances need shutoff valves?
Where should gas shutoff be located?
notes: The shutoff valve shall be within 6 feet of the appliance and shall be accessible.

title: Appliance Clearances
summary: Appliances shall be installed with clearances from combustible materials as specified in the manufacturer's instructions and the listing.
notes: Always refer to manufacturer's installation instructions for specific clearances. Typical minimum is 6 inches.

title: Smoke Alarms - Where Required
summary: Smoke alarms shall be installed in each sleeping room, outside each separate sleeping area, and on each story of the dwelling including basements.
common_questions: Where do smoke detectors need to be?
How many smoke detectors do I need?
notes: Smoke alarms shall be interconnected so that activation of one alarm activates all alarms in the dwelling.

title: Carbon Monoxide Alarms
summary: Carbon monoxide alarms shall be installed outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of the bedrooms in dwelling units with fuel-burning appliances or attached garages.
common_questions: Do I need carbon monoxide detectors?
notes: Required if dwelling has fuel-burning appliances (gas furnace, water heater, fireplace) or attached garage.

title: Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings
summary: Basements and every sleeping room shall have at least one operable emergency escape and rescue opening (egress window).
notes: Minimum opening: 5.7 square feet, minimum height 24 inches, minimum width 20 inches. Sill height maximum 44 inches from floor.

title: Habitable Room Requirements
summary: Habitable rooms shall have an aggregate glazing area of not less than 8 percent of the floor area. The minimum openable area shall be 4 percent of floor area.
common_questions: How much window area is required?
notes: Artificial light and mechanical ventilation may be substituted where natural light and ventilation are not adequate.
